text:
SPEAKER: One feature of
entrepreneurship in Chile now

is very low
participation by women.

What's your explanation
for that, or what could
be done to raise the ratio?

CHRISTOPH SCHIESS: Well,
that's a good question, which

we are not only having in Chile,
but also logically at many
parts of the world.

But definitely in Chile,
the participation of women

is still quite low compared
to other countries.

And there may be a
little bit traditional.

I'm living very near
because my wife,

she was selected
as the first woman

at the board of directors of
the stock exchange in Chile
after 123 years.

So in that sense,
it's an example.

And it is true that, at least
at the stock exchange quoted

companies, today
the participation

of women at the board of
directors is by 10% about,

compared with countries like, at
least, Germany, which is by 40.

Some countries ask to put
quotas and others not.

I think the quotas is
not necessarily healthy.

But the market has
to wake up and has

to say that it is
important to bring women

not only into the boards,
into the management,
into the whole staff.

Because somehow, what
we talked before,

the way of thinking of women
is different to the one of men.

And by now there are
studies and things,

but convincingly you will
have a much more integral,

different analysis of
problems if at the table,

you have not only
men but also women.

And in that sense, I would say
Chile, where logically there

is, through the whole positive
development of the last years,

the rate of women participating
at university studies

or other post-graduate
development is also increasing.

So you can see
that they are also

getting more into business, in
the more established companies,

but especially also in the
new startups or innovation.

We, for example, at
Endeavor again, we

see and also foster
that especially women
are developing a new business.

And I think this is a
development which comes,

but one can push it so
it comes a bit faster.
